# 1989–90 Sacramento Kings season

The 1989–90 Sacramento Kings season was the 41st season for the Sacramento Kings in the National Basketball Association, and their fifth season in Sacramento, California. The Kings won the NBA draft lottery, and selected power forward Pervis Ellison from the University of Louisville with the first overall pick in the 1989 NBA draft, and acquired Ralph Sampson from the Golden State Warriors during the off-season.
However, prior to the start of the regular season, the Kings were hit with tragedy when Ricky Berry, who had just completed a solid rookie season, committed suicide on August 14, 1989, at the age of 24; Berry died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head at his suburban home in Sacramento, after an argument with his wife, Valerie.
After a 7–21 start to the season, head coach Jerry Reynolds was fired and replaced with Dick Motta. At mid-season, the Kings traded Kenny Smith to the Atlanta Hawks in exchange for Antoine Carr. Injuries limited Ellison to only just 34 games, as the Kings finished in last place in the Pacific Division with a 23–59 record.
During the NBA All-Star weekend at the Miami Arena in Miami, Florida, and before the mid-season trade, Smith participated in the NBA Slam Dunk Contest. Following the season, Ellison was traded to the Washington Bullets, while Danny Ainge was traded to the Portland Trail Blazers, and Rodney McCray was dealt to the Dallas Mavericks.
